habitat.primary: Intestinal tract of warm-blooded animals (gut microbiota)
habitat.secondary: Surface water, soil, foods contaminated with fecal matter
habitat.conditions: Mesophilic; grows well at 20–45°C; neutral to slightly acidic pH; moisture required

contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Ranges from commensal to highly pathogenic depending on strain (opportunistic and pathogenic pathotypes)
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: Diarrhea (sometimes bloody), fever, abdominal pain; UTIs cause dysuria and frequency; systemic infections cause fever and sepsis
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: Many clinical E. coli strains carry plasmid-mediated resistance (e.g., ESBLs, carbapenemases in some isolates). Resistance varies by strain and geography.

foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Fecal contamination during slaughter, poor hygiene, cross-contamination from raw foods, contaminated irrigation or wash water
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Multiplies rapidly at room temperature (4–60°C); survives in acidic foods; produces toxins in some pathogenic strains
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Use hygienic slaughtering and processing, ensure pasteurization of milk, cook foods to safe temperatures, avoid cross-contamination, wash produce, use clean water
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: Cook ground beef to 71°C (160°F) and whole cuts to safe temperatures; reheat leftovers thoroughly; avoid raw milk
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Hold hot >60°C or cold <4°C; minimize time in 4–60°C danger zone
foodAssociation.storage: Keep perishable foods refrigerated below 4°C; avoid temperature abuse
foodAssociation.shelfLife: Raw meat: 1–2 days; milk (pasteurized): 7–10 days if refrigerated; produce: 3–5 days

biochemical.lactoseFermentation: Generally does not ferment lactose (on MacConkey appears non-lactose fermenter)

habitat.primary: Intestinal tract of animals (poultry, livestock) and humans
habitat.secondary: Contaminated food production environments, water, animal feces
habitat.conditions: Mesophilic; survives in a variety of environments including chilled and ambient temperatures; tolerant to a range of pH values

infections: Bacteremia and invasive disease in vulnerable patients
contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Several serovars are primary pathogens causing foodborne illness; can range from self-limiting gastroenteritis to invasive disease
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: Diarrhea, fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting; severe cases cause systemic infection and dehydration
contaminationAndHealthRisks.infectiousDose: 10³–10⁶ CFU (varies by serovar and host factors)
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: Resistance (including MDR and extended-spectrum beta-lactamases) is an increasing concern in some serovars and geographic regions

commonFoods: Raw produce contaminated with animal feces
Processed foods handled with poor hygiene
foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Contamination at slaughter or processing, contamination from infected animals or their feces, cross-contamination during handling
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Multiplies at room temperature; survives refrigeration; hardy organism; produces toxins in some cases
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Thorough cooking of poultry and eggs, pasteurization, strict hygiene in kitchens and processing plants, proper refrigeration, control at farm level
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: Cook poultry to at least 74°C (165°F); avoid consuming raw eggs; prevent cross-contamination between raw and ready-to-eat foods
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Hold hot >60°C or cold <4°C; minimize danger zone exposure
foodAssociation.storage: Keep raw poultry refrigerated; avoid long temperature abuse
foodAssociation.shelfLife: Raw poultry: 1–2 days; eggs: 3–4 weeks refrigerated

biochemical.amylase: Many species produce extracellular enzymes (amylases, proteases)

habitat.conditions: Often tolerant to dry conditions and wide temperature ranges; spores resist heat and desiccation

infections: Foodborne intoxication (Bacillus cereus) causing emetic or diarrheal syndromes
contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Most Bacillus are environmental; some species (e.g., B. cereus) are opportunistic foodborne pathogens
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: Emetic syndrome (vomiting) or diarrheal syndrome depending on toxin; rare systemic infections in vulnerable patients
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: Generally susceptible to many antibiotics but species-specific; spores make control in foods more difficult

commonFoods: Starchy foods left at room temperature
Reheated foods kept at improper temperatures
foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Spores survive cooking; improper cooling or storage allows growth and toxin production; cross-contamination from dust or raw ingredients
typicalSources: Cooked rice left at room temperature
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Grows in warm, neutral pH foods; spores survive cooking but germinate when cooled slowly
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Proper cooling and refrigeration after cooking, avoid prolonged room-temperature holding, thoroughly reheat leftovers, practice ingredient hygiene
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: Cool cooked rice rapidly, store below 4°C, reheat to piping hot throughout before serving
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Hot hold: >60°C; Cold hold: <4°C; Avoid 4–60°C 'danger zone'
foodAssociation.storage: Refrigerate promptly; keep hot foods >60°C if serving immediately

habitat.primary: Skin, nasal cavities, throat of humans and animals
habitat.secondary: Dairy products, food-processing surfaces, environmental contamination
habitat.conditions: Halotolerant (survives in high salt); grows well at body temperature; tolerates drying

contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Primary pathogen; produces multiple toxins including enterotoxins and Panton–Valentine leukocidin (PVL)
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: Sudden nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhea; skin infections cause pustules, abscesses; systemic infections cause fever and chills
atRiskPopulations: Those with wounds or indwelling devices
contaminationAndHealthRisks.infectiousDose: 10⁵–10⁸ CFU (for systemic infection); lower for preformed toxins
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: MRSA (methicillin-resistant S. aureus) is widespread; resistance to beta-lactams, fluoroquinolones, and macrolides reported

foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Direct contact from infected handler's hands or skin; cross-contamination from utensils or surfaces; can multiply and produce toxin at room temperature
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Grows rapidly at room temperature; produces heat-stable enterotoxins in 4–6 hours; toxins survive cooking
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Food handler hygiene, ban infected workers from handling food, prevent cross-contamination, cook to safe temps, refrigerate immediately after cooking
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: Ensure food handlers maintain high hygiene; cook to 74°C (165°F); serve hot foods immediately or refrigerate below 4°C within 2 hours
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Danger zone: 4–60°C (bacteria multiply and produce toxin); hold hot at >60°C or cold at <4°C
foodAssociation.storage: Refrigerate below 4°C; discard perishable foods left at room temp >2 hours (>1 hour if >32°C)
foodAssociation.shelfLife: Varies by product; typically 3–7 days refrigerated

Listeria monocytogenes.motility: Mobile at room temperature (peritrichous flagella); non-mobile at 37°C
Listeria monocytogenes.optimalGrowthTemperature: 37°C (body temp); grows slowly at refrigeration temps (4°C)

habitat.primary: Soil, vegetation, silage, contaminated dairy products
habitat.secondary: Intestinal tracts of animals and humans; food-processing environments
habitat.conditions: Psychrophilic (grows at refrigeration temps); salt-tolerant; survives at pH 4.3–9.6

contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Invasive pathogen; crosses intestinal barrier and blood–brain barrier; causes systemic infection particularly in vulnerable hosts
transmissionRoutes: Foodborne (contaminated dairy, deli meats, soft cheeses)
contaminationAndHealthRisks.symptomsTimeline: Variable (3–70 days); can be subclinical in healthy individuals
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: Fever, headache, body aches; meningitis: stiff neck, altered mental status; bacteremia: sepsis; in pregnancy: miscarriage or neonatal infection
atRiskPopulations: Immunocompromised (100–1000× higher risk than healthy individuals)
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: Naturally resistant to cephalosporins; susceptible to penicillins and ampicillin; TMP-SMX for penicillin-allergic patients

foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Contamination from soil/silage in dairy herds; inadequate pasteurization; post-processing contamination in deli or chilled foods
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Unique ability to grow at refrigeration temps; multiplies slowly in cold, but can reach infectious levels in weeks
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Pasteurization of milk, good sanitation in processing, avoid cross-contamination, maintain proper refrigeration, cook deli meats thoroughly
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: Cook all deli meats to steaming hot (74°C/165°F); avoid soft cheeses and unpasteurized products for at-risk groups; segregate raw foods
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Refrigeration at <4°C reduces but does NOT eliminate risk; growth occurs slowly even at 4°C over extended storage
foodAssociation.storage: Store at <4°C; limit storage duration of high-risk foods to 1–2 days; avoid prolonged cold storage
foodAssociation.shelfLife: Varies; deli meats 3–5 days if properly stored; soft cheeses 1–2 weeks

habitat.primary: Water (tap water, pools, hot tubs, soil), environmental surfaces
habitat.secondary: Hospital environments, medical equipment, food-processing settings
habitat.conditions: Prefers moist environments; grows in nutrient-poor water; produces biofilms

contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Opportunistic pathogen; primarily affects immunocompromised, hospitalized, or those with damaged epithelial barriers; produces multiple virulence factors including exotoxin A
transmissionRoutes: Direct contact with contaminated surfaces or equipment
contaminationAndHealthRisks.symptomsTimeline: Variable; can develop within hours (wound infection) to days
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: Wound infections: green/blue pus, odor; respiratory: productive cough, fever; systemic: sepsis symptoms; otitis: ear pain and discharge
contaminationAndHealthRisks.infectiousDose: Variable; opportunistic in nature; can establish with low inoculum in compromised hosts
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: Intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics; increasing resistance to fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, and carbapenems; biofilm formation limits antibiotic penetration

commonFoods: Less commonly causes foodborne illness; primarily waterborne or environmental
foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Contamination through water sources (inadequate treatment, biofilm in pipes); cross-contamination from moist environments; minimal risk through food if cooked
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Can survive in moist food environments but not a major foodborne pathogen; grows in water-rich foods if stored wet
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Environmental sanitation, water treatment, proper disinfection of equipment, moisture control, hand hygiene
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: For healthcare settings: use sterile water, clean equipment thoroughly, prevent cross-contamination
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Grows across temperature range; not controlled by temperature alone
foodAssociation.storage: Prevent moisture accumulation; keep surfaces dry

habitat.primary: Fermented foods (yogurt, kimchi, sauerkraut, kombucha), human gut microbiota, vaginal flora
habitat.conditions: Tolerates acidic conditions (pH 3.5–6.0); thrives in foods with low O₂ and presence of sugars

infections: Generally safe; rare opportunistic infections in severely immunocompromised (endocarditis, bacteremia)
contaminationAndHealthRisks.pathogenicity: Non-pathogenic to commensal; beneficial in most contexts; GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe) status
transmissionRoutes: Not a pathogen; present in fermented foods and human flora
contaminationAndHealthRisks.symptomsTimeline: No pathogenic symptoms in healthy individuals
contaminationAndHealthRisks.clinicalSymptoms: None (beneficial); may cause bloating in sensitive individuals when consumed as probiotic
atRiskPopulations: Extremely immunocompromised (near-zero CD4 count) at minimal risk
contaminationAndHealthRisks.antibioticResistanceConcerns: Intrinsic resistance to certain antibiotics (e.g., glycopeptides) is normal; not clinically concerning

foodAssociation.howContaminationOccurs: Not contamination—these bacteria are deliberately inoculated into foods for fermentation and preservation
foodAssociation.growthConditionsInFood: Ferments sugars to lactic acid, lowering pH and preserving food; thrives in dairy and vegetable substrates; beneficial for food safety and nutrition
foodAssociation.preventionAndControl: Maintain proper fermentation conditions (cool temps, anaerobic environment, clean equipment); beneficial bacteria prevent pathogenic overgrowth
foodAssociation.handlingAndCooking: Fermented foods should be handled gently; refrigeration extends shelf life; can be added to hot foods but excessive heat kills beneficial bacteria
foodAssociation.temperatureControl: Fermentation: 15–40°C (species and food dependent); storage: refrigerate to slow fermentation and maintain viability
foodAssociation.storage: Refrigerate fermented foods to slow fermentation; keep in anaerobic conditions (submersed in brine for vegetables, sealed for yogurt)
foodAssociation.shelfLife: Yogurt: 1–2 weeks; sauerkraut/kimchi: months to years if refrigerated; miso: 1–2 years in cool, dark place
